text:
Just read the first book last week after seeing this trailer for the first time.
This seems like a high production value series but as an adaptation I already see they are going to stray away from the source material in some ways.
There's a couple of characters here who seem to be pivotal to the show who don't appear in the books at all. I am conflicted about that but at the same time it might be a good way to keep the book readers on their toes.
At least they seem to be keeping the main story the same which is what matters. The scene with all the warriors and horses being pulled to the sky just makes me smile as I can't wait for people to actually see what was going on before that happened.

author: @fratguy1999
text:
(Incoming conflicting opinion) I just finished the first novel and I'm sorry but it is NOT a good book. (And I've been reading Sci-Fi my whole life). It reminds me of Asimov. Lots of great ideas. Very meh writing and characters. The beginning with the Chinese Cultural Revolution was well done and would make an endearing drama... But once the book goes Sci fi it's a bust. The characters are insanely flat (other than the cop who is one dimensional), the dialog is awful, the plot and motivations makes no sense, the plot holes are insane and anyone who knows anything about science or engineering will not be able to suspend disbelief. I have no idea how or why this won a Hugo. People keep raving but it feels like the Sci-Fi equivalent to "Fifty Shades of Grey". Insanely popular and not good. Project Hail Mary, blows 3BP out of the water and it didn't get a Hugo.... Maybe they read the first 60 pages and stopped there?

I really hope the show can add depth, rationality and personality to an otherwise meh book. There's tons of visual possibilities with all the fun science (just don't think about it) but we'll see.

author: @itzzzsss
text: This reminds me of a reoccurring dreams. Been spanning about 7 years now. It's up near where forest trees grow. There's a small stream that's very close to this one 2 story cabin structure. Mostly made of slightly brittle wood. My sight thinks the stream should be a little dirty. The stream ends towards a small strip of beach. Very close is a port. Just recently one of the unit on that wooden building had some sort of odd shrine. It was dedicated to American pornstars. One wall had portraits that look like family photos. But they were all American pornstars. Tried to look around one small wall, but it looked like someone artificially built it. Closing off a small room. There was 3 to 4 other people walking with me into that unit. We ended up in the master bedroom. All the room were empty except the livingroom with portraits hanging on the wall. Bedroom window was close to the stream. People were fishing in the semi dirty stream that led to the beach

text: I can't really put it into words on how this book series is like. Out of all the Sci-Fi books out there, the out of the box thinking all the crazy ideas people come up with to interest you into reading their book, the three body problem is on a completely different level. The second that you thought Syfy couldn't get any more insane then comes the three body problem. This is beyond Syfy because it's just so incredibly intelligent and smart. If a savant was a book it would be the three body problem. I love that they're making this into a series but to be honest with you, there is no television series, director or CGI that is going to give this series Justice. It's just too big for the big screen to give it the Justice it deserves.

author: @FlanaFugue
text:
I really liked the book The Three Body Problem and am looking forward to this Netflix adaptation. But I'm now reading The Dark Forest (finally) and I'm starting to have probelms with it... (Oh no! I want it to be so good so bad) The characters seem shallow... the plot doesn't make total sense... there's so much background exposition in every scene that one tends to forget what action and character it started off with...
SPOILER ALERT
The whole thing where Luo Ji got the perfect wife in the dream setting just to "blow off" the Wallfacer project was disappointing; I thought it was going somewhere, for example, this was all necessary before being able to take on the colossal endeavor of saving the world, or it was all necessary to inspire deep thought on what to do or something, or even some trick as a wallfacer, but, no... the U.N. had to manipulate him into caring?
Too often the story seems populated by characters imagined by an extremely cynical scientist who doesn't have much hope nor a very high regard for humans...
Dialogues often try to be overly clever - Characters sometimes say the opposite of what you expect only to contradict themselves a minute later, or at least say, oh wait I was wrong... it seems pointlessly confusing.
The Wallfacer project should be an absolute secret but the members have to submit their plans to the board for approval?
Are there any characters for us to actually relate to? I know it's sci-fi and not literature but I have no idea who I am supposed to be rooting for here, if anyone...
Can anyone talk me back into loving this series please???

text: Good lord. Please do this series justice, don't cancel it early based on initial viewing numbers. Let it grow and gain popularity by word of mouth like Stranger Things and don't cancel it early for god's sake. Also, writing. Effects don't make an amazing show (they add to it), the writing does (and the acting of that script). Please don't make the mistake so many other adaptations have that fail to follow the source material (Amazon's LotR, your own The Witcher series...). Do these simple things and this could be up there with Dark and Stranger Things as the best you've done. Also, what a travesty you canceled 1899. It's why it's hard to trust any streaming show anymore.

text: Well, I was excited ‚Ä¶ until ‚Äúfrom the creators of Game of Thrones‚Äù popped up. This first feeling of dismay was only intensified by the cast. For a book set in China with most characters being Chinese, most of these people aren‚Äôt? I‚Äôm aware some might be the scientists/philosophers within the game, but even so it seems they are already dissing source material - and I‚Äôm not saying there won‚Äôt be more in the actual series, but majority of the faces actually shown here definitely weren‚Äôt Chinese. It just looks like generic sci-fi, I saw no attempt to highlight the themes of the book at all beyond a quote that barely scratches the surface. I know it‚Äôs just a short trailer, but I‚Äôm getting a bad feeling ... and what‚Äôs with sword lady? I‚Äôve got a couple of ideas who she could be and/or what she is representing, but none of that comes up until book 3 so I‚Äôm kinda scratching my head

author: @HyperLuminal
text:
I really hope this is successful. I would love nothing more than for this to achieve enough momentum for the full trilogy to be adapted for the screen. Now, I‚Äôm a newer fan, having only discovered Liu‚Äôs body of work about a year ago but I was instantly captivated and dove in head first. It started with the first Wandering Earth movie which really piqued my interest, then I discovered much of his work including works of short fiction has been adapted in graphic novel format so I quickly consumed The Devourer, Butterfly, and Village Teacher. Finally I got into the novels, starting with the Remembrance(Three Body) trilogy. Needless to say, I‚Äôm very excited and hopeful that this is a quality adaptation.
Because I am truly exhausted from the volume of film adaptations of personally beloved IP‚Äôs resulting in lackluster disappointments that are promptly cancelled.

author: @austinmccool6132
text:
Been looking forward to this for a long time, though can't say I'm fans of D&D after what they did to Game of Thrones. However, they do seem to shine when they're adapting someone else's work rather than writing new material.

I don't think the trailer makes it look very good - doesn't really show the plot, and shows a confusing amount of timelines. I look forward to the show because I've wanted to read the books but hope they make a better trailer.

Also, single-digit numbers are normally written out. How the title of this show got through so many people and not once did someone correct it to, "Three-Body Problem," is beyond me - especially because the novel is, "The Three-Body Problem"! The name of the show has two grammatical errors, sounds like D&D's typical quality control.

text:
I heard so much good about this series and then I read it.

I'm a mathematician so it just spat in my face and kept doing so. You cannot ask people who know mathematics which actually deals in proof, truth and falsity to suspend disbelief over such a basic fact of your story.

So over and over I ran into the plot point and I just got more and more disgusted. Did the author just not know? Did he never bother to actually check? It isn't even material to the plot as when they finally describe the alien's situation it isn't actually a 3 body or n body problem at all, I get the author isn't a geometer or a physicist but do some research before writing for crying out loud.

author: @andy_robertson
text:
Never got onto the second book. Was really disappointed with the first.

It was so hyped up and from what I had heard about the plot, it sounded amazing.

Honestly can‚Äôt explain how much of a wasted opportunity this story is. The idea of it is fantastic, but by god the video game plot device could be single-handedly the dumbest idea in a book ever. It‚Äôs so ridiculous, you‚Äôd assume it was part of a Trisolaris plot to make you laugh yourself to death.

Totally ruins the book, and I‚Äôm genuinely gutted to see its part of this adaptation. Book fans will love it, but your casual fan will laugh at how absurd and nonsensical it is, and critics will tear it apart.

Won‚Äôt go beyond a second series.

author: @SomewhatSkating
text: I am BEYOND excited to see this series brought to film. And with that, I am also TERRIFIED knowing Netflix‚Äôs history. I hope more than anything they actually commit to three seasons, covering each book. Seeing Sophon is concerning, but I could understand how she may have just been placed in the simulation that the Three Body Problem was to begin with. It could make sense given what the simulation was. But I‚Äôm terrified to think that they spent this much time and effort into making the trilogy into a 10-episode miniseries. That just cannot work. The Dark Forest may just be the greatest singular sci-fi book of all time, and it NEEDS its own season to develop it. Please Netflix, we‚Äôre begging you, don‚Äôt give up on this. These three seasons could be some of the greatest ever produced on the silver screen.

author: @RADIOSUICIDIO
text: One thing to know about this saga is that is all about existential cosmic horror cleverly disguised as pseudo hard sci-fi. It's basically game theory mentality elevated to cosmic proportions, which is super intriguing (yes, I devoured the books), but also very ideologically biased, scientifically all over the place, and kind of effed up in a personal level. I'm not saying it's propaganda, but I learned to distrust anyone who makes claims and political stances basen on a suposed "human nature", let alone an "any-inteligent-life-in-the-cosmos nature". This one is a worst-case-scenario fantasy, that then goes on with a few "it's even worse" turns.

author: @actuallynotsteve
text:
I can't lie, this is my favorite book series ever. The 2nd book, The Dark Forest, is my favorite book of all-time. But when I heard it was getting made in to a show, I thought to myself "how could they make a show from this? It's literally unfilmable?" Hope I'm wrong, but the book is too crazy and insane to make into a show that reflects what we read in the book.

The 3rd book especially is so far beyond visual expression that I just can't see it. What's described in this book just goes beyond what any visual medium can really show us. If you haven't read it, this might sound impossible, but trust me - a 4d non-linear cosmos, among other things, just can't be "seen."

Maybe they're going in different directions.
